instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP3V0_G3H: What is PP3V0_G3H? PP3V0_G3H is a 3.0v power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won’t turn on after drop
threads.message:
Client says it was dropped and is dead.
Got 20V on charger and it takes around 1A from charger.

Nothing on screen, nothing on touch bar.
Trackpad clicks, caps lock light is not working.

CPU gets warm.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 13.03V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> = 13.03V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_OTH5V</SIGNAL> = 13.05V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_OTH3V3</SIGNAL> = 13.04V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S4_HS_TPAD</SIGNAL> = 13.04V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.41V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_SMC_ISNS</SIGNAL> = 3.40V
<SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL> = 2.99V
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 0.91V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5.01V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> = 5.13V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 5.13V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_KBD</SIGNAL> = 5.11V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.33V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3.33V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 3.30V

And got no idea what next…

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won’t turn on after drop
threads.message:
Probably broken solders/traces under some BGA chip.
Dropped machines are nightmare always...
